#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=THE RUBE
#Text=It was the most critical time I had yet experienced in my career as a baseball manager .
#Text=And there was more than the usual reason why I must pull the team out .
#Text=A chance for a business deal depended upon the good-will of the stockholders of the Worcester club .
#Text=On the outskirts of the town was a little cottage that I wanted to buy , and this depended upon the business deal .
#Text=My whole future happiness depended upon the little girl I hoped to install in that cottage .
#Text=Coming to the Worcester Eastern League team , I had found a strong aggregation and an enthusiastic following .
#Text=I really had a team with pennant possibilities .
#Text=Providence was a strong rival , but I beat them three straight in the opening series , set a fast pace , and likewise set Worcester baseball mad .
#Text=The Eastern League clubs were pretty evenly matched ; still I continued to hold the lead until misfortune overtook me .
#Text=Gregg smashed an umpire and had to be laid off .
#Text=Mullaney got spiked while sliding and was out of the game .
#Text=Ashwell sprained his ankle and Hirsch broke a finger .
#Text=Radbourne , my great pitcher , hurt his arm on a cold day and he could not get up his old speed .
#Text=Stringer , who had batted three hundred and seventy-one and led the league the year before , struck a bad spell and could not hit a barn door handed up to him .
#Text=Then came the slump .
#Text=The team suddenly let down ; went to pieces ; played ball that would have disgraced an amateur nine .
#Text=It was a trying time .
#Text=Here was a great team , strong everywhere .
#Text=A little hard luck had dug up a slump -- and now !
#Text=Day by day the team dropped in the race .
#Text=When we reached the second division the newspapers flayed us .
#Text=Worcester would never stand for a second division team .
#Text=Baseball admirers , reporters , fans -- especially the fans -- are fickle .
#Text=The admirers quit , the reporters grilled us , and the fans , though they stuck to the games with that barnacle-like tenacity peculiar to them , made life miserable for all of us .
#Text=I saw the pennant slowly fading , and the successful season , and the business deal , and the cottage , and Milly -- --
#Text=But when I thought of her I just could not see failure .
#Text=Something must be done , but what ?
#Text=I was at the end of my wits .

#Text=When Jersey City beat us that Saturday , eleven to two , shoving us down to fifth place with only a few percentage points above the Fall River team , I grew desperate , and locking my players in the dressing room I went after them .
#Text=They had lain down on me and needed a jar .
#Text=I told them so straight and flat , and being bitter , I did not pick and choose my words .
#Text=" And fellows , " I concluded , " you 've got to brace .

#Text=Connelly , I 've seen as fast a team in as bad a rut and yet pull out ,  returned Radbourne .

#Text= We 're about due for the brace .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Where on earth can I find such a pitcher ? " I shouted , almost distracted .

column1: #Text=" Well , that 's up to you , " replied Radbourne .
#Text=Up to me it certainly was , and I cudgeled my brains for inspiration .
#Text=After I had given up in hopelessness it came in the shape of a notice I read in one of the papers .
#Text=It was a brief mention of an amateur Worcester ball team being shut out in a game with a Rickettsville nine .
#Text=Rickettsville played Sunday ball , which gave me an opportunity to look them over .
#Text=It took some train riding and then a journey by coach to get to Rickettsville .
#Text=I mingled with the crowd of talking rustics .
#Text=There was only one little " bleachers " and this was loaded to the danger point with the feminine adherents of the teams .
#Text=Most of the crowd centered alongside and back of the catcher 's box .
#Text=I edged in and got a position just behind the stone that served as home plate .
